title: The useful formula here is: $${cos}^{2\left(\theta\right)}=\frac{1+cos\left(2\theta\right)}{2}$$ and $${sin}^{\theta}=\frac{1-cos\left(2\theta\right)}{2}$$
Using the sin formula above, rewrite $${sin}^{4\left(x\right)}$$ as $$\left(\frac{1-cos\left(2x\right)}{2}\right)^2$$

Use the cosine formula on $${cos}^{2\left(x\right)}$$. Then, expand the numerator after using the sin formula from earlier, and use the cosine formula on $${cos}^{2\left(2x\right)}$$. After multiplying together, you will have to use the cosine formula one more time on $${cos}^{3\left(2x\right)}$$. Using algebra, simplify from here.
